Attached is the Original Licensing Study Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the established violations, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, an original license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616)204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The Saint Clair Youth Treatment Center (SCYTC) will be a program operating
inside of and separately from the Macomb County Juvenile Justice Center. This
20-bed secure facility will be located on the first floor of this building. Upon arrival
to the facility there is a large parking lot where the front entrance to the Macomb
County JJC can be seen. The entrance to the SCYTC is located to the right of the
entrance to the Macomb facility, facing west. Upon entering the facility there are
several offices and administrative spaces and this eventually leads to a hallway
that moves east towards the units. There are two units with ten beds each
located in the south end of the building. Across from these units are two
classrooms. Moving further to the west side of the building allows access to a
gymnasium and an outside recreational space. Moving back east through a
hallway allows for access to five classroom spaces. Here a commons area and
large cafeteria space is available. A full kitchen is located to the east behind the
5

cafeteria. Continuing east back toward the front entrance of the building there is a
medical wing as well as a boiler room.
Within the secure parts of the building are four separate outdoor spaces for the
use of recreation of the youth, as well as a gymnasium space inside the building.
The section of the building being operated by SCYTC has seven classroom
spaces to meet the educational needs of youth.
An Environmental Health Inspection was approved as of 06/22/2023 resulting in
an “A” rating. A Fire Safety Inspection was completed on 11/14/2023 and the
Qualified Fire Inspector reported the agency has an “A” rating. The City of Mount
Clemens approved this property to be used in this capacity as of 08/15/2023. The
facility does have working cameras in multiple locations, and these have the
ability to record and save video.
B. Program Description
The Saint Clair Youth Treatment Center (SCYTC) is a secure private child caring
institution intended to provide residential services for juvenile justice youth as they
work towards placement back in a community setting. The facility will serve up to
20 male youth between the ages of 13 and 17. SCYTC will provide Evidence-
Based Mental Health Programming through a contract with the State of Michigan
Department of Health and Human Services. SCYTC will operate as a secure
setting to best ensure the safety of the male youth who have a history of
delinquent behaviors, mental health concerns, substance use patterns and needs
resulting from past trauma. This program is designed to serve youth who have
not been successful in less restrictive settings, as well as youth being released
from more restrictive settings working towards community placement.
All youth that will be considered for this program will be referred through the
MDHHS Juvenile Justice Assignment Unit, Care Management Organizations and
through court orders. No private placements will be considered. Youth that will
not be considered for placement in the program include medically fragile youth,
developmentally delayed and cognitively impaired youth, youth that present with a
need for in-patient mental health services as well as youth with severe sexually
maladaptive and/or reactive behaviors. Youth newly placed to the program will
receive an orientation program from a multidisciplinary team within the facility.
Highly structured days will provide appropriate expectations and predictability for
youth. SCYTC will utilize a behavior management curriculum based in social
learning theory and cognitive behavioral approaches. The intent of this is to
reinforce positive behavior for the youth. This behavior management system
consists of three separate phases ending with a youth in the highest level that can
show leadership skills, receive feedback and work towards self-efficacy.
Specifically, within this behavior management programming, restraints have been
approved for this facility by DCWL. The chosen restraint model is Safe Crisis
Management, which is nationally recognized and includes empirical support of
effectiveness. SCYTC will not use seclusion as a behavior management
6

intervention. Ratios of staff to youth will be 1:4 during daytime hours and 1:8
while youth are sleeping during nighttime hours. The SCYTC will follow an
integrated care model designed to meet each treatment need for a youth.
Nationally recognized and validated assessments will be used in treatment
planning. Therapeutic treatment will be provided to youth through a trauma
informed and strengths-based approach. They have committed to using
evidence-based programming such as Aggression Replacement Training, UCCI
Cognitive Behavioral Interventions for substance abuse, Thinking for a Change
and Seeking Safety groups. These interventions will be provided through
individual, group and family therapy services to help work towards the goal of the
youth being placed back in the community, a less restrictive setting or in the
parental home. SCYTC intends to integrate families into programming from the
beginning of a placement. Family therapy will utilize a Structural Family therapy
approach, families will have an assigned case manager for communication and
frequent visitation, home passes and daily contact via phone calls will be utilized.
Various and regular recreational opportunities for youth will be made available, as
well as off-site programming, community service, independent living and life skill
opportunities. Discharge planning begins upon admission and will continue after
the youth is placed elsewhere, offering six months of post-discharge services.
Medical care for youth placed in this program will be provided by staff within the
facility. Medical, dental and behavioral needs will be first identified within 24
hours of placement and then further health screening will occur within the next 30
days. It was confirmed on 11/13/2023 that an agreement was reached for
education to be provided on site through a contracted virtual learning service,
Success Virtual Learning Centers of Michigan. SCYTC will have
paraprofessionals working within the classrooms in coordination with the online
educational programming and all special education services required of youth will
be met.

Technical Assistance provided:
• All records for employee files, as well as future youth case files, shall be
organized in a uniform and organized manner and be in a complete status
at any time of review.
• All current and future employees should have position descriptions
provided to them and signed copies placed in their files to ensure clear
communication on job duties and requirements.
• Any prospective employees being considered for employment that have a
college degree will be required to have a “true copy” of documentation
verifying that degree, including documentation received directly from the
college or university or documentation noted by the facility that they viewed
and made a copy of the original degree.
• The facility will ensure that a date is noted on every referenced received at
the time of receipt while working through a prospective new hire.

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Due to established rule violations, a written corrective action plan is required. Upon
approval of the corrective action plan, a six-month original license is recommended.
